Title:
Molecular phylogeny of the luciferin binding protein gene in
marine gonyaulacoid dinoflagellates
Keywords:
bioluminescence, dinoflagellate, diversity, luciferin
binding protein, PCR, phylogeny
Abstract:
Dinoflagellate bioluminescence systems can operate with or
without a luciferin binding protein, representing two distinct modes of
light production. However, their distribution among bioluminescent
dinoflagellate groups remains unknown. This study used PCR to detect and
partially sequence a large part of the luciferin binding protein gene
(lbp) from a group of ecologically important bioluminescent gonyaulacoid
dinoflagellates. We report the presence of lbp for the first time in the
genera Ceratocorys, Gonyaulax and Protoceratium. Additionally, lbp is
shown to be widespread in bioluminescent species of Alexandrium.
Nucleotide sequences of lbp showed high variation among gene copies
within a single strain with identities as low as 90%, which was
consistent with the presence of more than one gene type. No relationship
was found between the presence of pseudogenes and bioluminescence.
Phylogenetic analyses of new and previously described lbp sequences
revealed highly divergent sequences that clustered in four distinct
clades, with sequences among them sharing less than 81% identity. While
the lbp sequences of Alexandrium species were intermingled in one clade,
Alexandrium monilatum lbp was found to be divergent from other
Alexandrium species and grouped with Gonyaulax spinifera, Ceratocorys
horrida and Protoceratium reticulatum; the lbp of these four species
were found to be closely related forming a single clade. Our results
reveal that lbp is more widespread among bioluminescent dinoflagellate
species than previously thought, and contributes to our understanding of
the mechanistic models of light production in phytoplankton.
